importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the January 6 Capitol riot through the 2025 arrest highlights the long-term legal and political consequences of the attack, including renewed threats and pardons.

keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a New York man convicted of Capitol riot-related offenses, was arrested for threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously pardoned by President Donald Trump alongside other January 6 defendants, sparking criticism from Jeffries over the blanket pardon.
Moynihan allegedly threatened to kill Jeffries in a text message stating: 'I will kill him for the future,' and claimed he would eliminate Jeffries after a public speech.
The New York judge has ordered Moynihan to remain in prison while awaiting a hearing on whether he can be released pending trial on a terroristic threat charge.
Moynihan has a history of opiate addiction and past drug-related offenses, which prosecutors and attorneys cited as factors in his political radicalization and mental health concerns.
Law enforcement is concerned about rising threats against public figures, especially in the wake of recent high-profile assassinations like that of Charlie Kirk.
Moynihan's actions during the Capitol riot involved taking photos of notes from a senator's desk, not attacking police or violently assaulting anyone.
The incident underscores growing concerns about the persistence of extremist rhetoric and violence following the January 6 attacks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A former participant in the January 6 Capitol riot, Christopher Moynihan, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan, who was previously pardoned by President Donald Trump, is accused of sending a text message stating he would 'kill him for the future' after Jeffries gives a speech in New York City. The New York judge has ruled that he remains in prison pending a hearing on a terroristic threat charge. The case underscores ongoing concerns about political violence, especially after recent assassinations like that of Charlie Kirk, and highlights Moynihan’s history of drug addiction and political radicalization. The incident also brings scrutiny to President Trump’s blanket pardon of January 6 defendants and the broader challenge of addressing extremist threats in American politics.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
